section.title: CVS
section.para: The best way to keep your CDK libraries up to date is to use Concurrent Version System. Linux/Unix distributions include this software. Other users may have to find a client for their platform on the internet (or download one of the packages below).
Information about how to get the CDK source code from CVS at SourceForge can be found here.

section.title: Source Packages
section.para: The source package can be downloaded here.

section.title: Unix, GNU/Linux, BSD tar.gz Package
section.para: CDK is distributed as a tar.gz source package from which it can be compiled. On Linux/Solaris/BSD systems, it can be installed with the normal ./configure && make && make install.

section.title: General Source Packages
section.para: On Windows systems CDK cannot be installed in an automized way as on Unix-like platforms, but it can be compiled with Ant: ant dist-all. However, a binary package can be downloaded too.

section.title: Binary Packages
section.para: The binary package can be downloaded here.

section.title: Debian GNU/Linux Packages
section.para: In addition to the source package, Debian user's can also download a Debian package. Keep in mind that the Debian package is uploaded to SF a few days later than the source package.
Debian users can also apt-get the package from debian.wgdd.de by adding the following to /etc/apt/sources.list:
section.literallayout: deb http://debian.wgdd.de/debian unstable main contrib non-free deb-src http://debian.wgdd.de/debian unstable main contrib non-free
section.para: Doing apt-get update && apt-get install libcdk-java/unstable. will then install CDK. (Jmol, Jchempaint and the CDK-plugins are also available from that apt-get repository.) The repository has changed, because mentors.debian.net will no longer provide binary-packages.

section.title: Windows Packages
section.para: For MS-Windows too, there is a binary package which includes two .bat files for running two of the command line utilities.
